abstract: For years, equipment once normally found only in the office has been migrating into the home, from answering machines and water coolers to laser printers and PCs. Now, in a quirky new campaign, Microsoft is hoping to sell America on the idea of bringing servers in-house.
snippet: For years, equipment once normally found only in the office has been migrating into the home, from answering machines and water coolers to laser printers and PCs. Now, in a quirky new campaign, Microsoft is hoping to sell America on the idea of br...
lead_paragraph: For years, equipment once normally found only in the office has been migrating into the home, from answering machines and water coolers to laser printers and PCs. Now, in a quirky new campaign, Microsoft is hoping to sell America on the idea of bringing servers in-house.

headline.main: What Next, Having the Office Christmas Party at Home?

abstract: Newer computer chips with multiple processors require dauntingly complex software and programmers are having a hard time keeping up.
snippet: Newer computer chips with multiple processors require dauntingly complex software and programmers are having a hard time keeping up.
lead_paragraph: REDMOND, Wash.  When he was chief executive of Intel in the 1990s, Andrew S. Grove would often talk about the “software spiral”  the interplay between ever-faster microprocessor chips and software that required ever more computing power.

headline.main: Faster Chips Are Leaving Programmers in Their Dust
headline.print_headline: Faster Chips Are Leaving Programmers In Their Dust

abstract: A startup takes an entire telephone company switchboard and makes it available over the Internet. This allows programmers to develop applications that combine telephone calls and other data.
snippet: A startup takes an entire telephone company switchboard and makes it available over the Internet. This allows programmers to develop applications that combine telephone calls and other data.
lead_paragraph: Can an untested Silicon Valley start-up with the slightly embarrassing name Ribbit take on corporate giants like Microsoft and Avaya?

headline.main: Would You Buy a Telephone From a Company Named Ribbit?
